Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Rapid field detection of crop pathogens using portable reflective interferometry
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a portable detector for pathogen testing of fruit crops in the field. The market for agricultural testing is over $20 billion per year, with greater potential for smaller firms for whom the current methods are impractical. Getting immediate results in the field is important since disease can spread through orchards in days and ruin entire crops. The proposed architecture may be applicable to point-of-care diagnostic sensors for food safety applications and for animal and human disease detection. <br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of an optical platform that is designed to produce large changes in reflectivity when small amounts of material adhere to its surface. The system uses a robust and convenient substrate, silicon, and a simple light-emitting diode, to implement the platform. Attached antibodies selectively bind specific pathogens of interest to the substrate in a way enabling the antibodies to recognize the appropriate target antigen even when immobilized on the surface. Sensitive detection is achieved through a process that discourages unwanted molecules from sticking to the surface.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key goal of this project was to assess the commercialization potential of a simple, potentially portable biomolecular sensing method developed in our lab. In principle, it can detect various pathogens and the main activity in the project was to test our hypothesis that this would be valuable for farmers and vineyard managers to test crops in the field. The result of extensive customer discovery interviews was that most farmers do not test and are not interested in doing so. However, we were able to pivot our focus to quality managers in food processing plants who were interested in a device like ours to test for food allergens. 

The intellectual merit of our proposed detection scheme is that it is very simple and only requires an instrument the size of a shoe box to do quantitative tests for meaningful levels of some allergens. Over the course of the proposal, we were able to go beyond our customer interviews and develop a first generation prototype of the instrument that we tested on model antigens. We were also able to develop a crude business plan to evaluate the prospects for commercialization. Preliminary data formed the basis for a follow-on proposal to the National Science Foundation's Partnership for Innovation program to do joint development with a Florida-based food assay company.

The broader impact of our work is in several different directions. First, our team and the student who is interested in commercialization of his work received entrepreneurship training that will be valuable to us whatever direction the project takes. We also made many contacts that will be able to help going forward. If we are able to successfully develop a test for allergens that can be done on site (and possibly even by consumers), it could have extensive consequences. Food allergies affect a large fraction of the population and are a growing concern. Beyond that, our detection approach is a platform technology that could be used for medical point of care diagnostics, water safety testing and other applications involving biomolecular detection using antibody probe molecules.
